title: How to Heal a Bruised Toe

steps.title: Apply ice to the bruise as soon as possible.
steps.content: Apply ice to the bruise as soon as possible. Put a towel-wrapped ice pack on your toe for up to 20 minutes at a time on the same day you get a bruise. [1] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Take it off after 10 minutes and reapply it after 20 minutes of rest. [2] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source This will reduce swelling and make the bruise hurt less. [3] X Research source Most bruises will fade and heal on their own in 2-4 weeks. Keep an eye on your bruised toe and see a doctor if a bruised toe or toenail doesn’t fade or gets worse after that amount of time. [4] X Research source If you don’t have an ice pack, you can use a bag of frozen vegetables wrapped in a clean towel. [5] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source

steps.title: Elevate the toe to reduce blood flow to it.
steps.content: Elevate the toe to reduce blood flow to it. Sit or lie down somewhere where you can put your foot up on something to elevate it above the level of your heart. This will reduce pressure to the bruised area and minimize the swelling. [6] X Research source For example, you could lie down on a couch and prop your foot up with a couple of cushions or pillows to elevate the bruised toe above heart level.

steps.title: Avoid heating the bruise for 2-3 days.
steps.content: Avoid heating the bruise for 2-3 days. Extreme heat will cause more swelling of the bruised area. Don’t take any particularly hot showers or baths or use warm compresses for the first 2-3 days after you bruise your toe. [7] X Research source Applying heat brings more blood to the surface. [8] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source

steps.title: Take painkillers if you need any pain relief.
steps.content: Take painkillers if you need any pain relief. Confirm with your doctor that you can take OTC painkillers for your injury, and double-check which ones are safe to use. Always follow the dosage instructions on the package when taking medication. [9] X Research source Painkillers that contain acetaminophen are Tylenol and Excedrin, for example.

steps.title: Tape the injured toe to the toe next to it to keep it stable.
steps.content: Tape the injured toe to the toe next to it to keep it stable. Put a small cotton ball between the 2 toes; then, wrap medical tape around them to keep your injured toe stable. Change the cotton and tape every day until the swelling goes down. [10] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source The cotton ball will help absorb moisture between the toes while they are taped together.

steps.title: Limit physical activity and pressure on the toe in the days after the injury.
steps.content: Limit physical activity and pressure on the toe in the days after the injury. Avoid any athletic activity until the bruise starts to fade. Try to avoid putting any strain on it by walking or standing for long periods of time. [11] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source You can return to regular amounts of walking and physical activity when the swelling is gone. Avoid wearing tight shoes while the toe is healing to keep pressure off it as well. Your doctor might be able to give you shoes with a stiff bottom, which is more accommodating to your injured toe.

steps.title: Apply warm compresses
steps.content: Apply warm compresses to the bruise after 2-3 days. Warm compresses help open up healthy blood vessels and boost healing. [12] X Research source Put a warm compress on the toe once a day for 15 minutes. [13] X Trustworthy Source HealthyChildren.org Health information from the American Academy of Pediatrics. Go to source A warm compress is a way to apply heat to part of your body. This can be done in many ways, for example, with warm water, microwaveable pads, hot water bottles, or electric heating pads.

steps.title: Rub a natural remedy, ointment, or oil on the bruise to help with healing.
steps.content: Rub a natural remedy, ointment, or oil on the bruise to help with healing. Apply a small amount of arnica ointment , St. John’s Wort oil , or vitamin K cream to the bruise. Follow the application instructions on the packaging, and always consult a doctor before using any natural remedies. Arnica, when applied topically, may help with bruising. [14] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source It comes in a variety of topical forms, including oil, ointment, and cream. Don’t take an oral supplement, though, as this can have negative side effects. [15] X Trustworthy Source Science Direct Online archive of peer-reviewed research on scientific, technical and medical topics Go to source St. John’s Wort oil to help with injury and pain. Hypericin, one of the active chemicals in this plant, affects your brain’s neurotransmitters. [16] X Trustworthy Source University of Rochester Medical Center Leading academic medical center in the U.S. focused on clinical care and research Go to source Research shows that vitamin K cream can lessen bruising after certain cosmetic treatments. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Trim your toenail short.
steps.content: Trim your toenail short. The shorter your nails are, the less likely they can grab onto something and get separated from your nail bed. [18] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Warning: Toenails are particularly susceptible to fungal infections after an injury. Keep an eye on your nail and visit a doctor if you notice it starting to separate from the skin underneath or if it becomes discolored after the bruise underneath heals. [19] X Research source If you trim your toenail flat instead of round, it will also help prevent an ingrown toenail. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Increase your vitamin C
steps.content: Increase your vitamin C and vitamin K intake. Vitamin C and K are both essential for healing. Get more vitamin C by eating citrus fruits and peppers and get more vitamin K by eating vegetables like broccoli and leafy greens. [21] X Research source You can also get more vitamins by taking a multivitamin or supplement every day. Flavonoids also help vitamin C work better in your body, especially when it comes to bruising. [22] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Hesperidin (a flavonoid especially helpful with bruising) is plentiful in oranges and lemons. [23] X Research source

steps.title: See a doctor if the bruised toe doesn’t seem to be healing after 2-4 weeks.
steps.content: See a doctor if the bruised toe doesn’t seem to be healing after 2-4 weeks. Pain and swelling usually subsides after a few days or a week and bruising usually doesn’t last any longer than 2-4 weeks. Visit a doctor if these symptoms last longer and healing seems to be going slower than normal. [24] X Trustworthy Source Seattle Children's Hospital Health information provided by Seattle Children's hospital. Go to source Even broken toes can heal on their own at home with the proper care. However, if your toe looks crooked after the injury, it’s a good idea to visit a doctor to make sure it doesn’t need to be straightened to heal properly. If you experience sudden numbness, tingling, or an increase in pain or swelling while the toe is healing during the first 2 weeks, visit a doctor as well.
